resources.string: Using intents means that you don\'t need permissions to add events. It\'ll just take you to the Calendar app and have you finish it up yourself.

If you\'re going to go for adding events in the background, you\'re going to use a sync adapter, which requires an account tied to your calendar to work. Here, we\'re just grabbing a random one. This can be okay or you could end up with events on your work\'s social calendar

In case you don\'t want to just add events to a random calendar, a local calendar can be a great option. It\'ll just create a new calendar to add events to. However, those events don\'t sync at all and you can only delete the calendar from the original app.
Let\'s try using a sync adapter to create a non local calendar now

So if you don\'t want a random account used, and also would like synced events for your users, you do have the option to have them select what calendar they use. Now the fun thing with getting all the calendars a user might have linked to their account is that it includes all the calendars for all accounts. So make sure you filter out the ones like, I don\'t know, your works social calendar you have permission to.
